title: Mrs. McKee interrupts. Tom jokes about McKee photographing Wilson. Catherine whispers about Tom and Myrtle getting a divorce.
text:
were startlingly white—changed hands and
settled down into Mrs. Wilson’s lap, where she fondled the
weatherproof coat with rapture.

“Is it a boy or a girl?” she asked delicately.

“That dog? That dog’s a boy.”

“It’s a bitch,” said Tom decisively. “Here’s your money. Go and buy
ten more dogs with it.”

We drove over to Fifth Avenue, warm and soft, almost pastoral, on the
summer Sunday afternoon. I wouldn’t have been surprised to see a great
flock of white sheep turn the corne

relations.explanation: The narrator states 'I first met Tom Buchanan’s mistress'.
The narrator describes Tom taking hold of his elbow and literally forcing him from the car, indicating a forceful interaction.
The narrator says 'I followed him', indicating he is accompanying Tom.
The narrator says 'George B. Wilson....and I followed Tom inside.'
Tom slaps Wilson jovially on the shoulder and discusses business.
Wilson wants to buy a car from Tom and asks 'When are you going to sell me that car?'
Tom responds coldly to Wilson's comment about the car, saying 'maybe I’d better sell it somewhere else after all.'
Myrtle shakes hands with Tom, looking him flush in the eye.
Myrtle walks 'through her husband as if he were a ghost'. She also speaks to him in a 'soft, coarse voice'.
Tom exchanges a frown with Doctor Eckleburg showing a negative sentiment.
Tom refers to Wilson as 'dumb he doesn’t know he’s alive' showing a clear disrespect.
Mrs. Wilson asks the dog seller about the puppies, showing an interest in buying one: 'What kind are they?' asked Mrs. Wilson eagerly, as he came to the taxi-window.
Mrs. Wilson says 'I think it’s cute' enthusiastically when referring to the dog.
The text describes Mrs. Wilson fondling the weatherproof coat with rapture after purchasing the dog.
